profileText: A Representative from Massachusetts; born in New Concord (now Lisbon), N.H., February 28, 1803; moved to Boston, Mass., with his parents in 1811 and to Hampden, Maine, in 1814; completed preparatory studies; at the age of eighteen moved to Eastport, Maine, and became employed as a clerk and afterward engaged in mercantile pursuits; editor of the Eastport Sentinel; founder of the Eastport Lyceum; incorporator of Eastport Academy and Eastport Athenaeum; member of the Maine house of representatives in 1833 and 1834; deputy collector of customs at Eastport 1841-1843; moved to Framingham, Mass., in 1848, having been appointed trial justice; elected as a Whig to the Thirty-second Congress to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Benjamin Thompson and served from December 13, 1852, to March 3, 1853; was not a candidate for the Thirty-third Congress; moved to Roxbury, Mass., having been appointed secretary of the Boston Board of Trade; also served as special agent of the United States Treasury Department; died in Roxbury, Mass., April 14, 1877; interment in Hillside Cemetery, Eastport, Washington County, Maine.

note.content: Elected to fill vacancy caused by death of Benjamin Thompson, and took his seat December 28, 1852.

researchRecord.name: 1821-1870, 4 boxes.
researchRecord.description: The papers of Lorenzo Sabine document his writings, and political activities. Subjects include capital punishment, the Civil and Revolutionary wars, dueling, fisheries, Indians, Loyalists, currency, justices of the peace, slavery, temperance, and women. Includes signature of Abraham Lincoln.

researchRecord.name: 1852, 1 page.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Lorenzo Sabine to Daniel Webster written on August 9, 1852. In the letter, Sabine writes he will meet with Webster to discuss the question of fisheries if possible.
